items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60 mAOD at 03:15 on 07/10/25 and 4.45 mAOD at 15:15 on 07/10/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock.

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 11 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next 5 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 07/10/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Higher than normal spring tides are forecast over the coming days. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
The first forecast high-water is 8:15 PM on 07/10/25 with a level of 7.61 mAOD and a Force 4 Westerly wind. The second forecast high-water is 8:45 AM on 08/10/25 with a level of 7.48 mAOD and a Force 3 Northerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high-water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level. Conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. 
Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.
Further flooding is possible at high-water until Thursday evening due to higher than normal tides. We are closely monitoring the situation and will be closing flood gates at Pill.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads where conditions may be hazardous.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 08/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings. High water at Ilfracombe on Tuesday evening is at 19:00, times of high water will vary along the coast.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and update on Wednesday
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Tuesday evening is 5.07 mAOD.

High tides are expected until the 10/10/25
 
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
The lunchtime tide today, 07/10/25 may reach flood alert, but the overnight tide tonight 07/10/25 will pass the flood alert threshold.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale at 12:30 AM on 08/10/2025. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
 
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
 
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 08/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
We do not expect to see impacts from the high tide this lunchtime, Tuesday 07/10/2025. However, high tides this evening may lead to flooding with the high tide expected at 11:00PM. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Flooding is possible Tuesday evening for Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods. 
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 07/10/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
High tides this afternoon may lead to flooding. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected. Flooding is possible around the high tide from 4:15 PM on 07/10/2025. Areas most at risk include riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads.
Tides are forecast to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying roads and footpaths. This message will be updated by this evening, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely today between 11:30am and 1:30pm today, Tuesday 7th October. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to approaching spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level tonight at Clacton of 2.73mAODN at 12:30pm on Tuesday 7th October which is 0.05m above tide tables, wind force 3, Westerly. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9 am tomorrow, Wednesday 8th October.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message: The forecast weather conditions during spring tides mean that high tides are expected between 06:30am and 08:30am on Wednesday 08 October 2025. Areas most at risk are Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 4.80mAODN at 07:30am, on Wednesday 08 October 2025, which is 0.13m above tide tables, wind Force 4, north-westerly. (mAODN is the height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide on Wednesday 08 October 2025 at 19:00pm is not currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am on Wednesday 08 October 2025.

The forecast weather conditions during spring tides, means that high tides are expected between 06:30am and 08:30am, Wednesday 08 October 2025. 

Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront. Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. 

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 4.80mAODN at 07:30am, on Wednesday 08 October 2025, which is 0.13m above tide tables, wind Force 4, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  

The following tide on Wednesday 08 October 2025 at 19:00pm is not currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate.  

We will update this message by 10:00am Wednesday 08 October 2025.

items.description: King's Lynn, West Lynn and The Wash frontage in Norfolk
items.message:
The forecast weather conditions during spring tides, means that high tides are expected between 06:30am and 08:30am, Wednesday 08 October 2025. 

Areas most at risk are King's Lynn, West Lynn, Clenchwarton, Terrington St Clement, Walpole Cross Keys and Tilney All Saints. 

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 4.80mAODN at 07:30am, on Wednesday 08 October 2025, which is 0.13m above tide tables, wind Force 4, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). 

The following tide on Wednesday 08 October 2025 at 19:00pm is not currently forecast to be a Flood Alert. 

Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. 

We will update this message by 10:00am Wednesday 08 October 2025.

A flood alert has been issued due to a period of high tides. Tides will be at their highest around 20:15 this evening 07/10/25 and between 08:30 and 08:45 on Wednesday 08/10/25. Flooding to roads and low-lying land adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow is expected at the time of high tides, however conditions may apply a few hours either side of the high tides. Predicted peaks at Newport 7.1m to 7.3m and Avonmouth 7.5m to 7.7m around 20:15 this evening Tuesday 07/10/25. Wednesday morning tide peaks Newport 6.9m to 7.2m and Avonmouth 7.4m to 7.6m. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 11:00 on 08/10/25, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels continue to recede following recent heavy rain.
Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
There are some showers today, but further flooding is not expected.
We continue to closely monitor the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 08/10/2025, or as the situation changes.
